Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter XX,.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter XX, Section XXX.
Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter XX,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter XX, Section XXX.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14 and 15..proposition: Plaintiff alleges a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, a violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, M.G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 15.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14.proposition: This complaint is based on the following Massachusetts statutes and caselaw: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, §§ 14 and 15; Pardo v. Lee, 459 Mass. 767 (2011); Kargman v. Worcester, 18 N.E. 2d 575 (1938); Cohen v. Boston Housing Auth., 53 N.E.2d 232 (1944); Davis v. Lipman, 160 N.E. 132 (1928); Abdallah v. Piedmont Grove Condo. Ass'n, 803 N.E.2d 242 (2004); Blaney v. White, 25 N.E. 330 (1890); Spinney v. Walters, 244 N.E.2d 221 (1969); Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Mass. 233 (1920); and Sequere v. Migra, 41 Mass. Apps. Ct. 349 (1996).

Pardo v. Lee, 459 Mass. 767 (2011);.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition lists Pardo v. Lee as part of a set of Massachusetts landlord-tenant and housing-related authorities under G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 15. The opinion excerpt provided is in fact from a criminal case concerning Commonwealth v. Chown, addressing probable cause for arrest and statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 90 (motor vehicle licensing and residency). It does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, or any of the housing-related issues referenced in the proposition, so it does not support that proposition.
Pardo v. Lee, 459 Mass. 767 (2011);.relevant_excerpt: “On January 20, 2006, the defendant, Kristian A. Chown, was stopped for speeding and then arrested for operating a motor vehicle without a license in violation of G. L. c. 90, § 10. … Because the arresting officer did not, in connection with the defendant’s arrest, take into account the statutory factors enumerated in G. L. c. 90, § 3½, for determining Massachusetts residency, and thus lacked probable cause to arrest the defendant for operating without a Massachusetts driver’s license, we affirm the order allowing the defendant’s motion to suppress.”

Abdallah v. Piedmont Grove Condo. Ass'n,.support_reasoning: The proposition lists Abdallah v. Piedmont Grove Condo. Ass'n as Massachusetts landlord-tenant/housing authority related authority (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, §§ 14 and 15, etc.). The provided opinion, however, is an Indiana criminal appellate case involving underage possession and consumption of alcohol, Miranda, corpus delicti, best evidence rule, sufficiency, and double jeopardy. It does not concern Massachusetts law, landlord-tenant issues, or the cited Massachusetts statutes, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
Abdallah v. Piedmont Grove Condo. Ass'n,.relevant_excerpt: “Appellant-defendant Tyler Lawson appeals his convictions for Illegal Possession of Alcohol and Illegal Consumption of Alcohol, both class C misdemeanors.… Thus, we affirm the consumption conviction but reverse Lawson's conviction for illegal possession of an alcoholic beverage.”

Spinney v. Walters, 244 N.E.2d 221 (1969.support_reasoning: The proposition lists a series of Massachusetts landlord-tenant and housing cases and statutes, but Spinney v. Walters is an Indiana criminal case about procuring a minor for prostitution. The opinion does not involve Massachusetts law, landlord-tenant issues, housing conditions, or any subject related to the cited statutes and cases. Accordingly, this case does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Spinney v. Walters, 244 N.E.2d 221 (1969.relevant_excerpt: “This action was commenced by affidavit on two counts, charging the defendant with the criminal offense of procuring a female for a house of prostitution pursuant to Burns’ Ind. Stat. Anno. § 10-4211. The defendant was found guilty under Count One and sentenced accordingly.”

Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Ma.raw_text: Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Mass. 233 (1920);
Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Ma.proposition: This complaint is based on the following Massachusetts statutes and caselaw: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, §§ 14 and 15; Pardo v. Lee, 459 Mass. 767 (2011); Kargman v. Worcester, 18 N.E. 2d 575 (1938); Cohen v. Boston Housing Auth., 53 N.E.2d 232 (1944); Davis v. Lipman, 160 N.E. 132 (1928); Abdallah v. Piedmont Grove Condo. Ass'n, 803 N.E.2d 242 (2004); Blaney v. White, 25 N.E. 330 (1890); Spinney v. Walters, 244 N.E.2d 221 (1969); Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Mass. 233 (1920); and Sequere v. Migra, 41 Mass. Apps. Ct. 349 (1996).
Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic reference to Massachusetts landlord‑tenant statutes and caselaw, largely involving interference with quiet enjoyment or related housing issues. Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co. is an eminent domain/real property boundary case about whether land within a way (Edwards Terrace) was released from a mortgage and applies the rule that a grant bounded "by" or "on" a way extends to the center line. It does not concern landlord‑tenant relations, G.L. c. 186, §§ 14–15, quiet enjoyment, or housing authority duties, so it does not support the proposition cited.
Meunier v. Frank G. Shattuck Co., 234 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "When a deed describes the land conveyed as bounded by or on a public or private way, the rule has long been established that the line of the granted premises extends to the centre of the way if owned by the grantor and if there is nothing in the deed to show a contrary intention. ... In construing the releases given by the original mortgagee, the general rule must be held to apply. They respectively released the land in Edwards Terrace to the centre of the way."
